awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Learning and Verifying Conformant Data-Driven Models for Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates fundamental techniques for building mathematical models that can be safely used to make trustworthy predictions and control decisions. Mathematical models form the foundation for modern Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). Examples include vehicle models that predict how a car will move when brakes are applied, or physiological models that predict how the blood glucose levels change in a patient with type-1 diabetes when insulin is administered. The success of machine learning tools has yielded data-driven models such as neural networks. However, depending on how data is collected and the models are learned, it is possible to obtain models that violate fundamental physical, chemical, or physiological facts that can potentially threaten life and property. The approach of the project is to expose these model flaws through advanced analysis. The project seeks to broaden participation in computing through mentoring activities that will encourage undergraduate women and members of underrepresented minority groups to consider a career in research.

The research combines falsification methods for exposing failure to conform with verification approaches for rigorously proving conformance. Furthermore, approaches for learning models of dynamical systems from data and imposing core cyber-physical domain knowledge are under investigation. The project is applying these data-driven models with conformance guarantees to the design of safe controllers for autonomous vehicles, models of human insulin glucose regulation and robotic swarms. The effort is advancing CPS education by creating a framework for distance education focused on CPS. The researchers are developing a series of low cost hardware testbeds and self-paced learning tasks that will expose students to the process of building highly reliable and safety critical CPS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of the project was to investigate how one can learn models of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) from data, such that the model satisfies key "conformance" properties that are specified a priori and independent of the data. This problem is of great importance to CPS since we wish to learn models of processes that satisfy criteria besides fitting the data well. Our initial work explored the importance of conformance and illustrated several cases wherein conformance failures caused dangerous situations using a non-conformant data-driven model to design control algorithms. One key outcome for our project was the development of fundamental algorithms that can learn switched dynamics models from data with important guarantees. Although learning a globally optimal model is well known to be computationally expensive, our work investigated the use of approximation algorithms and showed how to derive interesting approximation guarantees. The models inferred using such algorithms are able to predict the behaviour under previously unseen situations quite accurately. Another contribution lies in the use of learning to infer guaranteed control Lyapunov functions, which in turn allow us to extend a nominal controller to perform under conditions for which it was not designed. As an example, we showed that a controller designed to drive a vehicle along a "straight line" heading can be used over curved paths as long as the curvature was appropriately bounded. This bound is in turn derived from the control Lyapunov function. Finally, we showed how to repaire models to achieve some safety properties that were previously violated.

 

We applied our work on important medical cyber-physical systems as well as for autonomous driving on a 1/8th scale model car. Our approaches were applied to data from people with type-1 diabetes showing how simple piecewise affine models can be created to replace more complex nonlinear models. We also showed how to repair neural network control for smart prosthetics using techniques derived from this project. The  project led to further refinements of the 1/8th scale model car testbed at CU Boulder. Besides the research contributions, the project partly supported three PhD students and a REU student at CU Boulder.
